bibl.title: Letter from James M. Barnett to Dept. of Literary and Library Research, Mayo Clinic, January 5, 1942

div1.p: Barnett sends Hench some reprints, noting that Reed inspired Barnett's own work in the field of malaria research.

div1.head: Letter from James M. Barnett to Dept. of Literary and Library Research, Mayo Clinic, January 5, 1942
div1.opener:
DR. JAMES M. BARNETT
ALBANY, GA.
Albany, Ga.,
January 5, 1942.
Mayo Clinic,
Department of Literary & Library Research,
Rochester, Minn.
div1.p:
I am mailing you under separate
cover, copies of Reprints on malarial control which may
prove interesting to Dr. Hench.

Having reviewed recently, his article
on Yellow Fever in the “Proceedings,” lead me to believe
that these Reprints should be of some interest to him.

My work in malarial control in 1902,
was inspired by Major Reed, while in a conference with him
in Washington in 1902, when he came back from Cuba on a
rest period and returned in a few weeks thereafter to
rejoin his coworkers.
div1.closer:
Very cordially yours, J. M. Burnett JMB:jm.
Dr. Hench: I think this letter is self-
explanatory. The reprints are enclosed
and have been acknowledged.
Frida Pliefke, Librarian
